### INSTRUCTION:
Your task is to review some comments written by National Park data collectors to describe the visitation at their park for a given month. Analyze the comments and identify any months where specific locations were reported as closed. Your response should be 1-2 concise sentences. If no closures are mentioned, please respond with '<Month Name>: No Closures.'. Do not mention locations that are marked as using averages or estimates. Do not include closures that only happened for a few days or temporary closures due to weather or holidays. If you are unsure, default to no closures. The format should be as follows:
<Month Name>: <1-2 concise sentence summary of closures>.

### INPUT:
Comment for April:
4/17/2021  Memorial opened to the public.

### OUTPUT:
April: No Closures.
### END

The figure for "Estimate of Recreation Visits (not fishing) when the VC Closed" includes an estimate only for the Tuesdays and Wednesdays the VC is normally closed and the one (1) snow day; it does NOT include an estimate for the visitation not counted during the four days (TH-SUN, 4/27-4/30) when the VC was closed because of the flooding.

### INPUT:
Comment for February:
Shore Fisherman has picked up on the last year. On the weekend we average 50 vehicles a day at Bay of Chickens, Dillon Pinnacles has 25 vehicles, Sapinero has about 10-15, 35-40 at Dry Gulch, 10-15 at Elk Creek, 8-15 at Lake Fork, 5-10 at Iola and when the ice freezes on the west end there are less vehicles on the east end near Old Stevens and North Willow and that area averages 11-20 per day. During the weekdays it slows down to about 25-40 fisherman a day. This is the info I have and will start using to better estimate the amount of ice fishermen as it has picked up every year.  Other data was not entered for some reason during this month. 5 year estimate was used for this month with added to compensate for the higher number of visitation we received. As mentioned above Ice fishing has become more popular every year and it picked up.

### OUTPUT:
February: No Closures.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for January:
January 2024 was unseasonably warm and dry. This affected every component of winter operations:  * Trail counters were deployed later than normal. * Ice roads did not open at all in January (insufficient safe ice). * Two snowmobile trails remained closed all month. The remainder opened late. * Of the ski and snowmobile trails that opened, none could be groomed due to insufficient snow.  One trail counter had an error the prevented it from collecting data in January. In addition, the Echo Bay Ski Trail counter was replaced with a much higher-quality model, and this may account for higher ski use numbers.   The Rainy Lake Visitor Center and Kabetogama Lake Visitor Center--the latter of which was opened for winter use for the first time this year--were open on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays.  Commercial Use numbers are based on a 5-year average and will be updated with actuals once they are reported.  2/7/2024 MLDC

### OUTPUT:
January: Ice roads did not open, two snowmobile trails remained closed all month, and ski and snowmobile trails that opened could not be groomed due to insufficient snow. Rainy Lake Visitor Center and Kabetogama Lake Visitor Center were open on weekends.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for March:
March of 2024 was unseasonably warm and dry. No ice roads opened in winter 2024 due to insufficient ice conditions. The Sphunge Island sledding hill was also closed for the entire season. Snowmobile and ski trails could only be packed--not groomed--due to insufficient snow cover.   All lake-based snowmobile trails were closed much earlier than usual in winter 2024 due to abnormally warm temperatures and dangerous ice conditions.  Dates That Trails and Roads Closed:  Green Trail: 2/29/2024. Yellow Trail: 2/1/2024 Blue Trail: 2/14/24 Purple Trail: 2/22/24 Echo Bay Ski Trail: did not close but insufficient snow levels did not allow it to be used for skiing. Rainy Lake Rec Trail: did not close but insufficient snow levels did not always allow it to be used for skiing. Black Bay Ski Trail did not open in winter 2024.  The Kabetogama Lake Visitor was open during winter 2024 as a trial for possible future winter operations.   Commercial Use numbers are currently based on a 5-year average and will be updated once actuals are reported.

### OUTPUT:
March: Sphunge Island sledding hill was closed for the entire season, and lake-based snowmobile trails were closed much earlier than usual due to warm temperatures and dangerous ice conditions.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for August:
COVID-19 community infection levels were High for much of August and under these conditions the Exit Glacier Nature Center and the Visitor Center in Seward  were closed to the public.  There were Interpretive Rangers at the front door answering questions and visitors were counted if they came up to the door to ask questions.  This situation likely caused visitation to these two visitor centers to be lower than they would have been if the buildings were open.   Since the Visitor Center in Seward was closed much of the month, the # of visitors Viewing Video will be lower than it would have been if the building was open to the public. ### INPUT:
Comment for October:
Herman Leier Road was closed on Oct 28 and the vehicle classifier was removed.  There will no longer be vehicle traffic data collected for the winter.  Vehicle class count was estimated due to equipment failure. The vehicle classifier malfunctioned and was only collecting vehicle count data and did not collect vehicle classification data in October.  During the summer of 2019 we collected classifier data as a pilot project to determine if the park should change its visitor counting methods in the Exit Glacier area.  The 2022 Exit Glacier visitor use data has been very similar to the numbers collected in 2019, so it was determined with the guidance of the NPS statistics program to use the 2019 data to fill in for the missing data but ensuring that the total vehicle count collected in 2022, which was 500 vehicles higher than 2019, was incorporated into the final total vehicle counts.  Estimate of Other Backcountry Overnight Stays (from Park staff) are campers hiking the Harding Icefield trail and reporting camping in the trail register

### OUTPUT:
October: Herman Leier Road was closed on Oct 28, and the vehicle classifier was removed, resulting in no vehicle traffic data collection for the winter.
### END

Comment for January:
Non-reportable, non-recreation, and bus numbers are estimated due to partial government shutdown. The park was open, but measured data was not collected for the entire month. Estimates were produced using January 2019's most solid pieces of data, the South Entrance and Desert View traffic counters. The counter showed a 13% decrease in traffic at South Entrance and a 10% decrease in traffic at Desert View compared to January 2018. This decrease was applied across South District and Desert View January 2018 stats where needed to produce the January 2019 stats.  Mather Campground numbers are estimated due to partial government shutdown. Estimate produced from average number of nights/campers from January 26-31, 2019.

January: No Closures.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for November:
Due to a Winter Storm the North Rim closed for the year on November 26th.   Desert View Entrance station was closed November 26,27, and 28 due a winter storm.  A very impressive Thanksgiving snow storm created a park wide power failure from 3 AM on November 27th (Friday) to 1:45 AM on November 28th (Saturday). The City of Tusayan, located just outside our main gate, was also without power and declared a state of emergency. A number of state highways were closed as well as large portions of interstate 40 from the night of November 26th thru the morning of November 29. The two days, November 27 & 28, following Thanksgiving tend to be two of the busiest days of the year. But this year it was a bust.  The Maswik Lodge still has 35 rooms removed from service due to an ongoing construction project of new rooms.

### OUTPUT:
November: The North Rim closed for the year on November 26th due to a winter storm, and the Desert View Entrance station was closed on November 26, 27, and 28 also due to the storm. Maswik Lodge still has 35 rooms removed from service due to an ongoing construction project.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for February:
In 2018, one of our two counters ceased recording numbers (likely because of overgrown vegetation) in mid-June, and another appears to have been broken all year.  As a result, Forest Park visitors this year are estimated, using actual numbers for the first six months on one counter, and an extrapolation of data from the previous year for the other counter, based on the trends observed in the first six months on the semi-functional counter (an average increase in counts of ~9%).  As in past years, we were dividing the Mackenzie Road raw counter numbers by 2, as almost everyone who enters by that trail also leaves by the same trail; and for the Mountain Road counter, we were dividing by 1.5, as a decent number of people who enter by that trail depart by a different path.

### OUTPUT:
February: No Closures.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for April:
In 2018, one of our two counters ceased recording numbers (likely because of overgrown vegetation) in mid-June, and another appears to have been broken all year.  As a result, Forest Park visitors this year are estimated, using actual numbers for the first six months on one counter, and an extrapolation of data from the previous year for the other counter, based on the trends observed in the first six months on the semi-functional counter (an average increase in counts of ~9%).  As in past years, we were dividing the Mackenzie Road raw counter numbers by 2, as almost everyone who enters by that trail also leaves by the same trail; and for the Mountain Road counter, we were dividing by 1.5, as a decent number of people who enter by that trail depart by a different path.

### OUTPUT:
April: No Closures.
### END

### INPUT:
Comment for November:
Two items which need to be noted are the fact that the Cyclorama Center closed to the public as of November 20th, and the traffic counter on Hancock Avenue went down early in the month.  For the purpose of the report, I compared the traffic figures for West Confederate Avenue from this year as compared to November of 2004.  There was an increase of 3% on that road.  Therefore to come up with a fairly close estimate, I took the traffic count for Hancock Avenue in November of 2004 and multiplied it by 3%, coming up with the figure that I placed in the count for Hancock Avenue, November 2005.

### OUTPUT:
November: Cyclorama Center closed as of November 20th.
### END
